paper_title: Enhanced CO2 photoreduction activity of black TiO2−coated Cu nanoparticles under visible light irradiation: Role of metallic Cu

catalyst.source: To avoid this, black TiO 2 -coated Cu nanoparticles (denoted as CuTiO 2 ) were constructed in the present work, and their photoactivity for the photoreaction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor under visible-light irradiation was explored.
catalyst.context: Nanosized metallic copper could be a replacement of noble metals for improving photoactivity of TiO 2 -based photocatalysts, but it tends to be oxidized by oxygen in surroundings.To avoid this, black TiO 2 -coated Cu nanoparticles (denoted as CuTiO 2 ) were constructed in the present work, and their photoactivity for the photoreaction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor under visible-light irradiation was explored.X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy and selected area electron diffraction analysis for the used CuTiO 2 confirm the hierarchical structure of CuTiO 2 and oxygen resistance of metallic Cu.The photocatalytic activity for CuTiO 2 (4Cu) reaches 1.7 times of that for its counterpart, bared black TiO 2 .The improved photoactivity is attributed to the embedded metallic Cu, which promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies in TiO 2 through the metal-oxide interaction, thus increasing the visiblelight absorption of CuTiO 2 and the adsorption of CO 2 on their surface.Furthermore, the metallic Cu increases photoinduced charge-separation of TiO 2 through trapping electrons as evidenced by transient photocurrent measurements.The present work sheds light on developing new type of metal-oxide based visible-light-driven photocatalysts.

catalyst.source: The obtained photocatalysts with specific Cu content were denoted as TiO 2 , 1 CuTiO 2 , 2 CuTiO 2 and 4 CuTiO 2 , respectively.
catalyst.context: Cu nanoparticles (NPs) were synthesized through an approach using Al 2 O 3 as dispersing agent.CuO/Al 2 O 3 (CuO/Al 2 O 3 1/4, w/w) was firstly prepared by co-precipitation.Specifically, 11.7 g of Al(NO 3 ) 3 9H 2 O and 1.20 g of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 3H 2 O were dissolved in 100 mL of distilled water to form a solution (I).Then, 6.1 g of Na 2 CO 3 (AR) was dissolved in 100 mL of distilled water to form another solution (II).The two solutions were simultaneously dropwise added into a beaker containing 200 mL distilled water at 353 K under vigorous stirring.As-formed precipitate was washed thoroughly with distilled water.The filter cake was dried at 353 K and then calcinated at 723 K.The obtained CuO/Al 2 O 3 composite was dispersed into 4 M NaOH solution to obtain CuO NPs, which were further washed with distilled water, and then dried at 353 K.After that, the pure CuO NPs were reduced to CuNPs at 553 K in H 2 (99.999). A desired amount of Cu NPs (0, 20, 40 or 80 mg) was dispersed into 3 mL of ethanol containing 0.2 g water and hydrogen chloride (H 2 O/HCl/C 2 H 5 OH, pH 3).Following that, 0.84 g of Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 was dissolved in 3 mL of ethanol and dropwise added into Cu NPs suspension under ultrasonic wave.The mixture was transformed into gel after about 40 min.The gel was heated to 150 C to remove ethanol, butanol and HCl.The above steps carried out under the protection of H 2 flow.Finally, the sample was annealed at 450 C for 2 h under high vacuum.The obtained photocatalysts with specific Cu content were denoted as TiO 2 , 1 CuTiO 2 , 2 CuTiO 2 and 4 CuTiO 2 , respectively. The chemical compositions of photocatalysts were analyzed by an ARL-9800 X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF).The surface area and pore size were determined using a Micromeritics ASAP2020 autosorption analyzer.Experiments were carried out at 77.3 K using N 2 as an adsorbate.The samples were degassed at 473 K for 2 h before the measurements.X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were collected in ambient atmosphere by a Bruker D8 powder diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation ( 1.5408A) generated at 40 kV and 30 mA.Diffraction intensities were recorded from 20 to 80 at a rate of 2 /min.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterization was performed on a JEOL-JEM 2100 electron microscope.Absorption spectra of the photocatalysts were recorded via a ShimadzuSolidSpec-3700DUV spectrophotometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment with a spectraloncoated integrating sphere against spectralon reference.The EPR measurements were carried out on a Bruker E500 instrument operating in the X-band and equipped with an Oxford cryostat working in the temperature range of 4-298 K.The samples (20 mg) were placed into a spectroscopically pure quartz cell and sent into the ESR cavity with fixed depth.All the spectra were recorded at 100 K. g-Values were determined by calibration with DPPH (Bruker spectrometer) standard.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) study was performed using a VG Microtech MT500 with an Mg-K Xray source.All binding energies were referenced to carbon (1s) at 285.6 eV. Adsorption of CO 2 was carried out on a home-made volumetric adsorption system at room temperature.The catalysts were evacuated at 423 K for 2 h before the measurements.After cooling the catalysts to room temperature, doses of CO 2 were admitted sequentially and the coverage of CO 2 was measured until the equilibrium pressure reached about 9 kP a .The uptake of CO 2 for the saturation coverage on a photo-catalyst surface was determined by extrapolating the coverage of isotherm to P CO 2 0. The photocurrent was measured with a CHI660E instrument using a three-electrode system.The samples (50 mg) were loaded on conductive surface of ITO glass and 0.05 M Na 2 SO 4 solution was used as electrolyte.500 W Xenon lamp equipped with UV cut-off filter ( 400 nm) was used as light source, standard calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode, and Pt slice as counter electrode. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor was carried out in a reactor connected with mechanical vacuum pump.The powder of photocatalysts (20 mg) was evenly deposited on a circular quartz plate with diameter of 50 cm and then located inside the photo-reactor perpendicular to the light beam.A 500 W Xe lamp (Oriel) coupled with UV cut-off filter was used as light source with light intensity of 0.220 W cm -2 .Thus, the wavelengths of light were mainly located between 400 and 800 nm.Gaseous CO 2 of 8 kP a was in site produced in reactor by a reaction of NaHCO 3 (Analytical Grade) with 0.5 mol/L H 2 SO 4 solution.The products of O 2 , CO and CH 4 were analyzed in situ by a gas chromatograph (Agilent Technology 4890 GC) with a TCD equipped with Porapark Q and Molsieve 5 A column with H 2 as carrier gas.The possible prod-Table 1 Composition, specific surface area and pore structure of the TiO2, 1 CuTiO2, 2 CuTiO2 and 4 CuTiO2 photocatalysts calcinated under vacuum at 723 K. Catalyst ucts of C 2 -C 5 hydrocarbons and methanol were detected with a FID detector equipped with an HP-5capillary column.

catalyst.source: The photocatalytic activity for CuTiO 2 (4 Cu) reaches 1.7 times of that for its counterpart, bared black TiO 2 , which is attributed to the charge-separation and the visible-light absorption enhancements in CuTiO 2 nanoparticles.
catalyst.context: In summary, black TiO 2 -coated Cu nanoparticles (CuTiO 2 ) were fabricated in the work.The TiO 2 coating protects the metallic Cu nanoparticles from oxygen oxidation under the photocatalytic reaction condition.TiO 2 annealed under vacuum shows strong absorption in visible-light region, while the addition of metallic Cu nanoparticles further enhances the visible-light absorption of TiO 2 .Electron paramagnetic resonance and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analyses reveal a large amount of oxygen vacancies presents in the bulk and on the surface of TiO 2 .The metallic Cu nanoparticles promote the formation of oxygen vacancies in TiO 2 through the metal-oxide interaction, which accounts for the enhanced visible-light absorption of CuTiO 2 .Moreover, the enhanced amounts of oxygen vacancies lead to an increase in the adsorption of CO 2 on the surface of CuTiO 2 as compared to black TiO 2 .Transient photocurrent measurements indicate the addition of the metallic Cu effectively increases the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs of TiO 2 through trapping electron.The photocatalytic activity for CuTiO 2 (4 Cu) reaches 1.7 times of that for its counterpart, bared black TiO 2 , which is attributed to the charge-separation and the visible-light absorption enhancements in CuTiO 2 nanoparticles.The present work provides a new and efficient strategy for protection of metallic Cu against oxidation, leading to improved photocatalytic activity. A desired amount of Cu NPs (0, 20, 40 or 80 mg) was dispersed into 3 mL of ethanol containing 0.2 g water and hydrogen chloride (H 2 O/HCl/C 2 H 5 OH, pH 3).Following that, 0.84 g of Ti(OC 4 H 9 ) 4 was dissolved in 3 mL of ethanol and dropwise added into Cu NPs suspension under ultrasonic wave.The mixture was transformed into gel after about 40 min.The gel was heated to 150 C to remove ethanol, butanol and HCl.The above steps carried out under the protection of H 2 flow.Finally, the sample was annealed at 450 C for 2 h under high vacuum.The obtained photocatalysts with specific Cu content were denoted as TiO 2 , 1 CuTiO 2 , 2 CuTiO 2 and 4 CuTiO 2 , respectively. The chemical compositions of photocatalysts were analyzed by an ARL-9800 X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF).The surface area and pore size were determined using a Micromeritics ASAP2020 autosorption analyzer.Experiments were carried out at 77.3 K using N 2 as an adsorbate.The samples were degassed at 473 K for 2 h before the measurements.X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were collected in ambient atmosphere by a Bruker D8 powder diffractometer with Cu Ka radiation ( 1.5408A) generated at 40 kV and 30 mA.Diffraction intensities were recorded from 20 to 80 at a rate of 2 /min.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) characterization was performed on a JEOL-JEM 2100 electron microscope.Absorption spectra of the photocatalysts were recorded via a ShimadzuSolidSpec-3700DUV spectrophotometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment with a spectraloncoated integrating sphere against spectralon reference.The EPR measurements were carried out on a Bruker E500 instrument operating in the X-band and equipped with an Oxford cryostat working in the temperature range of 4-298 K.The samples (20 mg) were placed into a spectroscopically pure quartz cell and sent into the ESR cavity with fixed depth.All the spectra were recorded at 100 K. g-Values were determined by calibration with DPPH (Bruker spectrometer) standard.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) study was performed using a VG Microtech MT500 with an Mg-K Xray source.All binding energies were referenced to carbon (1s) at 285.6 eV. Adsorption of CO 2 was carried out on a home-made volumetric adsorption system at room temperature.The catalysts were evacuated at 423 K for 2 h before the measurements.After cooling the catalysts to room temperature, doses of CO 2 were admitted sequentially and the coverage of CO 2 was measured until the equilibrium pressure reached about 9 kP a .The uptake of CO 2 for the saturation coverage on a photo-catalyst surface was determined by extrapolating the coverage of isotherm to P CO 2 0. The photocurrent was measured with a CHI660E instrument using a three-electrode system.The samples (50 mg) were loaded on conductive surface of ITO glass and 0.05 M Na 2 SO 4 solution was used as electrolyte.500 W Xenon lamp equipped with UV cut-off filter ( 400 nm) was used as light source, standard calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode, and Pt slice as counter electrode. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor was carried out in a reactor connected with mechanical vacuum pump.The powder of photocatalysts (20 mg) was evenly deposited on a circular quartz plate with diameter of 50 cm and then located inside the photo-reactor perpendicular to the light beam.A 500 W Xe lamp (Oriel) coupled with UV cut-off filter was used as light source with light intensity of 0.220 W cm -2 .Thus, the wavelengths of light were mainly located between 400 and 800 nm.Gaseous CO 2 of 8 kP a was in site produced in reactor by a reaction of NaHCO 3 (Analytical Grade) with 0.5 mol/L H 2 SO 4 solution.The products of O 2 , CO and CH 4 were analyzed in situ by a gas chromatograph (Agilent Technology 4890 GC) with a TCD equipped with Porapark Q and Molsieve 5 A column with H 2 as carrier gas.The possible prod-Table 1 Composition, specific surface area and pore structure of the TiO2, 1 CuTiO2, 2 CuTiO2 and 4 CuTiO2 photocatalysts calcinated under vacuum at 723 K. Catalyst ucts of C 2 -C 5 hydrocarbons and methanol were detected with a FID detector equipped with an HP-5capillary column.

reaction medium.context: Nanosized metallic copper could be a replacement of noble metals for improving photoactivity of TiO 2 -based photocatalysts, but it tends to be oxidized by oxygen in surroundings.To avoid this, black TiO 2 -coated Cu nanoparticles (denoted as CuTiO 2 ) were constructed in the present work, and their photoactivity for the photoreaction of CO 2 with H 2 O vapor under visible-light irradiation was explored.X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy and selected area electron diffraction analysis for the used CuTiO 2 confirm the hierarchical structure of CuTiO 2 and oxygen resistance of metallic Cu.The photocatalytic activity for CuTiO 2 (4Cu) reaches 1.7 times of that for its counterpart, bared black TiO 2 .The improved photoactivity is attributed to the embedded metallic Cu, which promotes the formation of oxygen vacancies in TiO 2 through the metal-oxide interaction, thus increasing the visiblelight absorption of CuTiO 2 and the adsorption of CO 2 on their surface.Furthermore, the metallic Cu increases photoinduced charge-separation of TiO 2 through trapping electrons as evidenced by transient photocurrent measurements.The present work sheds light on developing new type of metal-oxide based visible-light-driven photocatalysts.
